Ideal corresponding to a subset
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).
Noetherian ring

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Reduced ideal

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
Splitting Field of Polynomial
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
Separable extension
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
Galois extension
An extension $K_{r} / K$ is Galois if it is both normal and separable.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Solvable group

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
Group Action

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Stabilizer
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The stabilizer or isotropy subgroup of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G_{x}:=\{g \in G ; g x=x\}$.
Centralizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
Center
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Galois extension is a specialization of a separable extension, as it requires the extension to be both normal and separable, thus inheriting all properties of a separable extension and adding additional constraints.

The concept of an Orbit is a specialization of Group Action, as it directly utilizes the definition and properties of a group acting on a set to define the set of elements reachable from a given point under the group action.

The concept of a Stabilizer is a specialization of Group Action, as it uses the group action to define the subgroup of elements that leave a particular point unchanged, thus inheriting the properties of group actions.

The Center of a group is a specialization of the Centralizer concept, specifically it is the centralizer of the entire group itself, thus inheriting all properties of centralizers and applying them to the group as a whole.
